Award.AwardTitle: DMREF/Collaborative Research: Designing and Synthesizing Nano-Metallic Materials with Superior Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Often, the main factor limiting the performance of vehicles, power generators, civil engineering structures, and many other products is the durability of the metals they are made of. Better metals are therefore key to advancing technologies at the core of US competitiveness and security: transportation, energy, and infrastructure. Nano-metallic materials comprise a class of metals that promise to fill this need: they possess extreme strength, resistance to damage from repeated loading, and numerous unique properties such as resistance to radiation damage. This research project addresses a drawback of nano-metallic materials that has so far limited their practical use. Namely: when they stretch, they do not elongate uniformly throughout, but rather pinch off in isolated locations. This project will create nano-metallic materials that stretch uniformly and are therefore not prone to sudden failures. It will thereby remove a major impediment to the widespread technical use of nano-metallic materials and accelerate their deployment to the marketplace. This project will also undertake outreach activities to high school teachers and students, women, individuals from underrepresented minorities, and the broader scientific community.

Even though many nano-metallic materials are intrinsically ductile, they appear to fail in a brittle-like manner because plastic deformation in them localizes into narrow zones that subsequently fracture. The goal of this project is to create nano-metallic materials that resist flow localization by engineering their architectures, interfaces/surfaces, and compositions via an iterative design process that integrates theory, modeling, and experiments. The project will follow an iterative design-synthesize-test cycle that scans the design space rapidly and integrates insights gained in each iteration by updating theoretical models connecting design parameters to performance metrics. Due to the nanometer-scale microstructure dimensions in nano-metallic materials, conventional dislocation-based mechanisms for averting flow localization are not applicable. Therefore, this project will explore and implement non-dislocation mechanisms that rely on twinning, surface and interface stresses, coherency stresses, interface barriers to slip, confined layer slip, and composites of flow-localizing and uniformly deforming constituents.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced the basic understansing  of metallic nanostrucutres and nanocomposite materials.  Thw studies addressied mechanical behavior, specifically  flow localization, i.e. the tendency of the material to fail suddenly due to an acute concentration of mechanical deformation in a limited volume.

We studied the effects of the large surface and interface area in these materials, and developed models for the resulting tension/compression assymetry. 

We addressed metallic nano-foams and  nanocomposites in different morphologies.  The approach was a combination of experiments and atomistic level simulations.    We tested these materials using nano- indentation and micropillar compression, and particularly virtual tensile and compression testing using simulation techniques.  The simulations and experiments can be performed at similar length scales, thanks to large-scale parallel computing techniques. Our findings suggest that the flow localization depends on microstructure morphology. These results open new paths to designing materials with reduced susceptibility to flow localization.  We specifically addresssed brittle behavior of metallic foams under tension and clarified the failure mechanisms of these materials. We showed that failure proceeds by the straining of individual nano-ligaments.  The  clear correspondance of experiments and simulations was a key success of this work. 

Additionally, our work led to  new types of hierarchical nano- composite metallic  structures . This is is a new area of investigation in  metal nanocomposites that has been opened up by this project. Our combined experiment/simulation techques allowed for the clear understanding of how applied loading is distributed in the various parts of the composite, an important tool for composite design. 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/09/2020
Modified by: Diana Farkas
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project advanced the basic understansing of metallic nanostrucutres and nanocomposite materials. Thw studies addressied mechanical behavior, specifically flow localization, i.e. the tendency of the material to fail suddenly due to an acute concentration of mechanical deformation in a limited volume. We studied the effects of the large surface and interface area in these materials, and developed models for the resulting tension/compression assymetry. We addressed metallic nano-foams and nanocomposites in different morphologies. The approach was a combination of experiments and atomistic level simulations. We tested these materials using nano- indentation and micropillar compression, and particularly virtual tensile and compression testing using simulation techniques. The simulations and experiments can be performed at similar length scales, thanks to large-scale parallel computing techniques. Our findings suggest that the flow localization depends on microstructure morphology. These results open new paths to designing materials with reduced susceptibility to flow localization. We specifically addresssed brittle behavior of metallic foams under tension and clarified the failure mechanisms of these materials. We showed that failure proceeds by the straining of individual nano-ligaments. The clear correspondance of experiments and simulations was a key success of this work. Additionally, our work led to new types of hierarchical nano- composite metallic structures . This is is a new area of investigation in metal nanocomposites that has been opened up by this project. Our combined experiment/simulation techques allowed for the clear understanding of how applied loading is distributed in the various parts of the composite, an important tool for composite design.
